title: New Film by Errol Morris: Separated
content:
Separated is the newest documentary film from Errol Morris. Based on Jacob Soboroffâ€™s 2020 book Separated: Inside an American Tragedy, the film probes the inhumane family separation and immigration policies of the Trump administration. From a review in The Guardian:

The Trump administrationâ€™s southern border policy began with the dream of a wall in the desert and ended with the nightmare of family separation: children torn from their parents and loaded en masse into wire-mesh cages. It was inhumane treatment, which was precisely the point. The White Houseâ€™s intention was to use terror as a deterrent and effectively write every parentâ€™s worst fear into law. â€œWhen you have that policy, people donâ€™t come,â€ Donald Trump said blithely. â€œI know it sounds harsh, but we have to save our country.â€

Errol Morrisâ€™s forensic, procedural documentary walks us through the bureaucratic backrooms to show how the policy was hatched and implemented. It explains how its principal authors â€” Trump adviser Stephen Miller and attorney general Jeff Sessions â€” junked the pre-existing catch-and-release scheme (which had allowed migrants to remain in the country until their immigration hearing) in favour of a bold new tactic of forced separation and mass imprisonment. If Separated lacks the rueful exuberance that typifies much of Morrisâ€™s early work (The Thin Blue Line, The Fog of War, even last yearâ€™s John le CarrÃ© film), that is entirely understandable. The material is sobering and the mountain of evidence needs unpicking. The film-maker handles his brief with the cold, hard precision of an expert state prosecutor.

From a Variety review:

â€œHarm to children was part of the point,â€ says Jonathan White, a committed public servant who saw his department, the Office of Refugee Resettlement, hijacked by a blatantly inhumane strategy that the Trump administration implemented for its deterrent potential. â€œThey believed it would terrify families into not coming.â€ White isnâ€™t exactly a whistleblower, although he comes across as no less courageous in describing a dictated-from-the-top family separation scheme for which he had a front-row seat.
